response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this measure is to transfer the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and General Services and establish the Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund. [CHUNK_116] This measure was amended by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts and changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_121] The authorized uses of the Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund were also amended to exclude the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service. [CHUNK_120]",
  "appropriations": "The appropriations in the bill for fiscal year 2025-2026 have been changed to unspecified amounts. [CHUNK_120] The Committee on Economic Development & Technology respectfully requests the Committee on Finance to consider the appropriation amount of $200,000 (HB934_HD1_HSCR329_.htm.txt) to be deposited into and appropriated out of the Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund. [CHUNK_122] The Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism asked that the $200,000 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) appropriation in the measure be added to the general fund line item as opposed to the special fund. [CHUNK_13]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "Testimony from the Office of Enterprise Technology Services indicates that the FY 26 operating budget request by the HBDEO is $777,090 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) for personal services and other expenses. [CHUNK_44] This requested amount increases to $964,815 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) by FY 31. [CHUNK_44] These figures contrast with the committee's recommended appropriation of $200,000 (HB934_HD1_HSCR329_.htm.txt). [CHUNK_122]",
  "agency_impact": "According to testimony, taking over the responsibility of running and managing the Hawaiʻi Broadband and Digital Equity Office would be a huge endeavor for the Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS). [CHUNK_35] To be successful in this transfer, ETS recommends that the special fund needs to fully cover all staff salaries and benefits, program priorities, operational expenses and any additional overhead, for five years until the special fund may become self-sustaining. [CHUNK_45] ETS also recommends adding language to the bill for “Funding positions for personnel and other necessary operating expenses to provide technical assistance to the community.” [CHUNK_42]",
  "economic_impact": "The federal and state governments have committed over $400 million to modernize our subsea and terrestrial infrastructure. [CHUNK_3] Hawaii is slated to receive over $200 million in federal grants for broadband infrastructure in the immediate future. [CHUNK_60] In 2023, Charter extended its network to reach an additional 9,000 homes and small businesses in Hawaii, investing $96 million (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) across the state. [CHUNK_65]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure was amended to change the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_121] A key policy change is the exclusion of the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service from the authorized uses of the Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund. [CHUNK_120] The bill also repeals Chapter 206S, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [CHUNK_98]",
  "revenue_sources": "While the bill allows for appropriations by the legislature to the special fund, the latest version of the bill changed the appropriation out of general revenues to an unspecified amount. [CHUNK_99] With the construction of new subsea broadband infrastructure, our state anticipates generating revenue from negotiated lease agreements. [CHUNK_4] The fund can also receive gifts, donations, and grants from public agencies and private persons. [CHUNK_95]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "Although the bill's appropriation for fiscal year 2025-2026 is unspecified, testimony from the Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS) provides a different fiscal outlook. [CHUNK_120] The FY 26 operating budget request by the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) is $777,090 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) for personal services and other expenses, which increases to $964,815 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) by FY 31. [CHUNK_44] ETS recommends that, in order for the program to be successful with the responsibilities outlined in the bill, the special fund needs to fully cover all staff salaries and benefits, program priorities, operational expenses and any additional overhead, for five years until the special fund may become self-sustaining. [CHUNK_45] The transfer of employees will be without loss of salary, seniority, or other benefits. [CHUNK_103] The comptroller may prescribe the duties and qualifications of these employees and fix their salaries without regard to chapter 76, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [CHUNK_108]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The state anticipates generating revenue from negotiated lease agreements with the construction of new subsea broadband infrastructure. [CHUNK_4] These proceeds of leases of broadband infrastructure owned by the State shall be deposited into the broadband and digital equity special fund. [CHUNK_94] The special fund will also receive gifts, donations, grants, and any interest earned or accrued on moneys deposited into the fund. [CHUNK_95]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The amended measure specifies that moneys in the broadband and digital equity special fund shall be used for supporting broadband projects, but explicitly excludes the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service. [CHUNK_96] This change was made to ensure that broadband adoption efforts and broadband availability efforts are each given the independent attention needed to properly address these very different issues. [CHUNK_63] All existing equipment, machines, and other personal property of the Hawaii broadband and digital equity office will be transferred with the functions to which they relate. [CHUNK_109]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "Testimony from the Office of Enterprise Technology Services states the operating budget request by the HBDEO increases to $964,815 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) by FY 31, indicating a significant ongoing fiscal obligation beyond the initial six-year period. [CHUNK_44] The special fund is designed to become self-sustaining through revenues from leases and other sources. [CHUNK_45] The long-term success of the office will depend on the special fund's ability to fully cover all staff salaries and benefits, program priorities, and operational expenses. [CHUNK_45]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The primary updates from the previous fiscal note are based on amendments to the bill and new information from testimony. [CHUNK_120] The appropriations for FY 2025-2026, previously set at $200,000, have been changed to unspecified amounts in the bill text, although the committee report recommends considering the appropriation amount of $200,000 (HB934_HD1_HSCR329_.htm.txt). [CHUNK_122] The bill's effective date has been changed to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_121] A significant policy change excludes the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service from the authorized uses of the special fund. [CHUNK_120] Furthermore, testimony introduced substantially higher budget projections for the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office, with a requested operating budget of $777,090 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 2026, increasing to $964,815 (HB934_TESTIMONY_ECD_02-05-25_.PDF.txt) by FY 2031. [CHUNK_44]"
}

5, 2025 Testimony on H.B. 934 - RELATING TO THE HAWAII BROADBAND AND DIGITAL EQUITY OFFICE Chair Ilagan, Vice-Chair Hussey, and Members of the Committees: Thank you for the opportunity to provide testimony in support of H.B. 934 which transfers the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) from the

the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism (DBEDT) to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS) in the Department of Accounting and General Services, establishes the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund, and appropriates additional funding. Reliable, affordable high

Equity Special Fund, and appropriates additional funding. Reliable, affordable high speed internet access is essential for ensuring greater educational, economic, and social opportunities for all. The federal and state governments have committed over $400 million to modernize our subsea and terrestrial infrastructure and equip residents with the tools and knowledge

terrestrial infrastructure and equip residents with the tools and knowledge to safely navigate the internet. With the construction of new subsea broadband infrastructure, our state anticipates generating revenue from negotiated lease agreements and the creation of a special fund will ensure these funds are used to reduce the cost of

ensure these funds are used to reduce the cost of internet services, provide technical assistance to communities, and support broadband projects. Given the increasingly vital role of broadband in our daily lives, the transfer of HBDEO from DBEDT to ETS provides an opportunity to consolidate and centralize broadband responsibilities currently

provides an opportunity to consolidate and centralize broadband responsibilities currently dispersed across state government, including those of the Hawaii Broadband Assistance Advisory Council and other reporting requirements. Our office will work closely with the relevant departments to compile all broadband functions for the Legislature’s consideration. Thank you for the opportunity

functions for the Legislature’s consideration. Thank you for the opportunity to provide testimony in support of H.B. 934. JOSH GREEN, M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. THE HAWAII BROADBAND AND DIGITAL EQUITY OFFICE. Chair Ilagan, Vice Chair Hussey and members of the Committee. The Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism (DBEDT) provides the following comments on HB934 that transfers the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in

Office (HBDEO) to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and General Services. HBDEO has provided steady leadership in state broadband and digital equity. I am confident that regardless of where the Office resides in state government, the Office will continue to provide the necessary leadership

government, the Office will continue to provide the necessary leadership and accountability in carrying out its statutory responsibilities and in deployment and management of federal funds. DBEDT will continue to collaborate with the Office as it is an important piece to the future of digital workforce and economic development. We

to the future of digital workforce and economic development. We ask that the $200,000 appropriation in the measure be added to the general fund line item as opposed to the special fund as the funds are necessary for standard operations and to support the processing of contract invoices. Thank you

and to support the processing of contract invoices. Thank you for the opportunity to testify. for underserved and vulnerable populations. OFFICE The Department of Budget and Finance (B&F) offers comments on this bill. House Bill (H.B.) No. 934: 1) transfers the Hawai‘i Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) from the Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and

of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and General Services; 2) establishes the Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund (BDESF) to be administered by HBDEO for the purposes of supporting broadband projects, defraying the cost of internet services, and funding positions for personnel to provide technical assistance for

and funding positions for personnel to provide technical assistance for the community; 3) appropriates $200,000 in general funds for FY 26 to be deposited into the BDESF; and 4) appropriates $200,000 in special fund ceiling for the BDESF for FY 26. As a matter of general policy, B&F does not

26. As a matter of general policy, B&F does not support the creation of any special fund, which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.3, HRS. Special funds should: 1) serve a need as demonstrated by the purpose, scope of work, and an explanation why the program cannot be

of work, and an explanation why the program cannot be implemented successfully under the general -2- fund appropriation process; 2) reflect a clear nexus between the benefits sought and charges made upon the users or beneficiaries or a clear link between the program and the sources of revenue; 3) provide

between the program and the sources of revenue; 3) provide an appropriate means of financing for the program or activity; and 4) demonstrate the capacity to be financially self-sustaining. Regarding H.B. No. 934, it is difficult to determine whether the BDESF would be self-sustaining. Thank you for your consideration of

BDESF would be self-sustaining. Thank you for your consideration of our comments. As the State and broadband service providers navigate the evolving landscape of broadband infrastructure and funding with the new federal administration, we must consider strategic approaches that maximize efficiency and align with federal initiatives. The Broadband Equity, Access, and Deployment (“BEAD”) Program, which allocates $42.45 billion to expand high-speed internet access, presents a unique opportunity for our state to enhance its broadband capabilities. The state's share of BEAD funding is $149.5M plus $46M in state matching funds to increase broadband infrastructure and promote digital literacy services. Additionally, as a broadband service provider, Hawaiian Telcom continues

navigators and literacy tools, affordability programs, and access to hardware. Charter believes that every Hawaii resident should have reliable access to the Internet. We will continue to help bring the benefits of broadband and access to the internet to those who need it most. Hawaii is slated to receive over $200 million in federal grants for broadband infrastructure in the immediate future (via the Broadband, Equity, Access, and Deployment Program), in addition to private investments already being made by the industry. The Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund should prioritize funding projects related to broadband adoption and affordability programs, rather than

of dollars to ensure that all households in Hawaii will soon have high-speed broadband available. Infrastructure availability and digital equity are both important, but they are different problems requiring different, independent solutions. In 2023, Charter extended its network to reach an additional 9,000 homes and small businesses in Hawaii, investing $96 million across the state. Charter participated in the FCC’s Emergency Broadband Benefit Program (EBB) and Affordable Connectivity Program (ACP), which helped connect over 59,000 eligible households in Hawaii with high-speed broadband. Your Committee finds that reliable, affordable high speed internet access is essential for ensuring greater educational, economic, and social opportunities for all. This measure addresses this need

and social opportunities for all. This measure addresses this need by transferring the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services to consolidate and centralize broadband responsibilities currently dispersed across state agencies and establishing the Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund.
